Beethoven among the paintings

Beethoven among the paintings - the complete Beethoven cello works in 2 concerts at Great Hall, Bishop’s Palace, Hereford - Friday 11th, Saturday 12th November 2022

The artists:

  • Jan Škrdlík - cello,
  • Petra Besa - piano,
  • Jana Rosie Dvořáková - paintings inspired by Beethoven’s compositions on display at concert

Concert program

There are two programs that cover the complete Beethoven cello works in 2 concerts - if there is sufficient demand from those who cannot make the Friday and Saturday concerts then the Friday 11th program may also be repeated on the Thursday 10th and the Saturday 12th program on Wednesday 9th.

Friday 11th Nov (also Thurs 10th Nov if sufficient demand)

  • Sonata G minor for piano and cello, Op. 5, No. 2
  • 12 Variations on a Theme from Handel’s Oratorio Judas Maccabeus, WoO45

Interval

  • 7 Variations on a Theme from Mozart’s The Magic Flute, WoO46
  • Sonata C major for cello and piano, Op 102, No. 4

Saturday 12th Nov (also Wed 9th Nov if sufficient demand)

  • Sonata F major for piano and cello, Op. 5, No. 1
  • Sonata A major for cello and piano, Op 69, No. 3

Interval

  • 12 Variations on a Theme from Mozart’s The Magic Flute, Op. 66
  • Sonata D major for cello and piano, Op 102, No. 5

To book

contact me, Richard Wilson, on 07565 539 764 (text preferred) or email: concert@fizzandbuzz.co.uk.

Tickets are:

  • £18;
  • £14 (back three rows).
  • Students: half-price,
  • Children: free

Payment by cheque, BACS, or cash on the door.

Logistics:

Bishop’s Palace is by Hereford Cathedral (on Google Maps search “373M+F9 Hereford” - or on What 3 Words https://w3w.co/pound.never.windy )

Mask wearing will not be required but a mask - especially an FFP2 mask - could help protect yourself and others.

  1. From https://www.gov.uk/government/statistics/national-flu-and-covid-19-surveillance-reports-2022-to-2023-season COVID-19 COVID-19 levels as of mid October 2022 seem equivalent to the 2010-11 flu season - the worst flu season of the last dozen years or so - about 4 times worse than a normal flu season. So a good mask seems a good idea especially if the level rises.
  2. As at mid October, for week ending 17th October, about 1 person in 30 in England tested positive ( 3.5% in West Midlands and 4.1% in those aged 50-69yrs old tested positive) according the Office of National Statistics Coronavirus Infection Survey so folks wearing masks help guard against the possibility that you or someone you are sitting near to at the concert is someone who would test positive and might infect people.
  3. In four out of the 6 months April to Sept 2022 this Office of National Statistic mortality analysis indicates COVID-19 is a top 10 cause of funeral music (and influenza and pneumonia was a top 10 cause in all 6 of those months). So wear a mask and help avoid unpleasant & premature musical performances.
